Award.AwardTitle: RUI: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: The ecology of Anaplasma phagocytophilum: Reservoirs, risk, and incidence
Award.AbstractNarration: This research will investigate the ecology of human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA), an emerging disease on three continents and examine the effects of species diversity on disease transmission. HGA is caused by a rickettsial bacterium, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, that is transmitted from host to host through the bite of an infected ixodid tick. The research will include a characterization of reservoir competence of wildlife hosts and determine whether host reservoir competence is a function of coinfection with the bacterium that causes Lyme disease. The researchers will build and test models to predict how risk of human exposure to HGA will vary with changes in the diversity and species composition of host communities. They also will experimentally evaluate specific mechanisms underlying effects of variable diversity on risk by manipulating key hosts in natural communities. Finally, they will educate local health-care providers about this emerging disease and expand the HGA surveillance capabilities of the local (Dutchess County, NY) health department. The enhanced surveillance data will be used to test for spatial correlations between ecological risk and human incidence. The project will train more than 40 undergraduates and provide for them an opportunity to conduct independent research. Understanding disease transmission dynamics is crucial for the appropriate management of communities and landscapes to reduce the total burden of zoonotic disease.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human granulocytic anaplasmosis is a rapidly emerging infectious disease of humans. Most reported cases of HGA in the U.S. are concentrated in north central and northeastern states, though cases have been documented in 35 of the 50 states. HGA has also been documented throughout Europe and Asia. HGA is caused by a bacterium, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, that is passed from host to host, including humans, through the bite of infected ticks. The ticks that transmit A. phagocytophilum feed from a wide variety of vertebrate host species. If they feed on a host infected with A. phagocytophilum, they may acquire the infection and become dangerous to humans.

We determined the species of animals from which ticks acquire infection with A. phagocytophilum and the proportion of ticks that pick up infection. By developing a new method of detection, we refined our results to focus only on the strain of A. phagocytophilum that is known to cause symptoms in humans. White-footed mice (Peromyscus leucopus) and eastern chipmunks (Tamias striatus) were the hosts most likely to transmit this strain of A. phagocytophilum to feeding ticks. Interestingly, our research has shown that these two host species are also responsible for transmitting Borrelia burdorgeri, the bacterium that causes Lyme disease, to feeding ticks at the highest rate of all species. We have also found that they, along with another small mammal, the short-tailed shrew (Blarina brevicauda), are the most important hosts for the pathogen that causes babesiosis, another emerging infectious diseases of humans. In conclusion, three species of small mammals are the animals most responsible for transmitting three emerging pathogens to humans.

We continue to investigate why all three pathogens show such a similar pattern in hosts. However, for this project, we have focused primarily on the consequences of this result. In particular, we have shown that ticks are much more likely to be coinfected with multiple pathogens than expected by chance, which is critical information for health care providers and the public. We have also investigated how changes to ecological communities affect the probability that ticks will be infected with any of these pathogens. For example, the fragmentation of habitats reduces the diversity of vertebrate hosts. The most common vertebrate hosts that remain in fragmented forests of the eastern United States are the same three species that are the most likely to transmit the three emerging pathogens to feeding ticks. Thus, we predict that ticks from fragmented habitats should be more likely to be infected than ticks from more intact forest habitats. Our results from hundreds of sites across Dutchess County appear to support this hypothesis.
